title: Scottish Enlightenment: Moral Sense to Political Economy
description: The Scottish moral philosophy tradition from Shaftesbury's moral sense through Hutcheson (Smith's teacher), Mandeville's provocations, to Hume's radical empiricism. Foundation for Adam Smith's synthesis of moral sentiments and economic theory.

keyFigures.name: Shaftesbury
keyFigures.contribution: Moral sense - virtue appreciated like beauty

keyFigures.name: Hume
keyFigures.contribution: Passions over reason, sentiment-based morality, skepticism

intellectualInfluence: Direct lineage to Adam Smith: Hutcheson (teacher) + Hume (friend) → Theory of Moral Sentiments (1759) → Wealth of Nations (1776)
researchValue: Essential for understanding the philosophical foundations of classical economics. Shows how moral philosophy becomes political economy through the Scottish tradition.
